member.name: T:InRule.Common.Interop.SQLite.SQLiteNativeProxy
member.summary: Hold onto your lunch... This is probably the best way to achieve: 1) Least amount of code-maintenance if we need to upgrade sqlite3 or the SQLite ADO.NET wrapper, 2) No intermediate objects to handle JIT-Loading 32-bit or 64-bit Interop Assembly - Static delegates call the P/Invokes directly.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConvert.Split(System.String,System.Char)
member.summary: Smart method of splitting a string. Skips quoted elements, removes the quotes.
member.remarks:
This split function works somewhat like the String.Split() function in that it breaks apart a string into pieces and returns the pieces as an array. The primary differences are:
Only one character can be provided as a separator character
Quoted text inside the string is skipped over when searching for the separator, and the quotes are removed.
Thus, if splitting the following string looking for a comma:
One,Two, "Three, Four", Five
The resulting array would contain
[0] One
[1] Two
[2] Three, Four
[3] Five
Note that the leading and trailing spaces were removed from each item during the split.
member.param: Source string to split apart
Separator character
member.returns: A string array of the split up elements

member.remarks: "yes", "no", "y", "n", "0", "1", "on", "off" as well as Boolean.FalseString and Boolean.TrueString will all be converted to a proper boolean value.

member.summary: Prepares a SQL statement for execution.
member.param: The source connection preparing the command. Can be null for any caller except LINQ
The SQL command text to prepare
The previous statement in a multi-statement command, or null if no previous statement exists
The timeout to wait before aborting the prepare

The remainder of the statement that was not processed. Each call to prepare parses the SQL up to to either the end of the text or to the first semi-colon delimiter. The remaining text is returned here for a subsequent call to Prepare() until all the text has been processed.

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection
member.summary: SQLite implentation of DbConnection.
member.remarks:
The ConnectionString property of the SQLiteConnection class can contain the following parameter(s), delimited with a semi-colon:
Parameter Values Required Default
Data Source {filename} Y
Version 3 N 3
UseUTF16Encoding True
False N False
DateTimeFormat Ticks - Use DateTime.Ticks
ISO8601 - Use ISO8601 DateTime format N ISO8601
BinaryGUID True - Store GUID columns in binary form
False - Store GUID columns as text N True
Cache Size {size in bytes} N 2000
Synchronous Normal - Normal file flushing behavior
Full - Full flushing after all writes
Off - Underlying OS flushes I/O's N Normal
Page Size {size in bytes} N 1024
Password {password} N
Enlist Y - Automatically enlist in distributed transactions
N - No automatic enlistment N Y
Pooling True - Use connection pooling
False - Do not use connection pooling N False
FailIfMissing True - Don't create the database if it does not exist, throw an error instead
False - Automatically create the database if it does not exist N False
Max Page Count {size in pages} - Limits the maximum number of pages (limits the size) of the database N 0
Legacy Format True - Use the more compatible legacy 3.x database format
False - Use the newer 3.3x database format which compresses numbers more effectively N False
Default Timeout {time in seconds}
The default command timeout N 30
Journal Mode Delete - Delete the journal file after a commit
Persist - Zero out and leave the journal file on disk after a commit
Off - Disable the rollback journal entirely N Delete
Read Only True - Open the database for read only access
False - Open the database for normal read/write access N False
Max Pool Size The maximum number of connections for the given connection string that can be in the connection pool N 100
Default IsolationLevel The default transaciton isolation level N Serializable

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection.BeginTransaction(System.Data.IsolationLevel,System.Boolean)
member.summary: OBSOLETE. Creates a new SQLiteTransaction if one isn't already active on the connection.
member.param: This parameter is ignored.

When TRUE, SQLite defers obtaining a write lock until a write operation is requested. When FALSE, a writelock is obtained immediately. The default is TRUE, but in a multi-threaded multi-writer environment, one may instead choose to lock the database immediately to avoid any possible writer deadlock.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection.BeginTransaction(System.Boolean)
member.summary: OBSOLETE. Creates a new SQLiteTransaction if one isn't already active on the connection.
member.param: When TRUE, SQLite defers obtaining a write lock until a write operation is requested. When FALSE, a writelock is obtained immediately. The default is false, but in a multi-threaded multi-writer environment, one may instead choose to lock the database immediately to avoid any possible writer deadlock.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection.BeginTransaction(System.Data.IsolationLevel)
member.summary: Creates a new SQLiteTransaction if one isn't already active on the connection.
member.param: Supported isolation levels are Serializable, ReadCommitted and Unspecified.
member.remarks: Unspecified will use the default isolation level specified in the connection string. If no isolation level is specified in the connection string, Serializable is used. Serializable transactions are the default. In this mode, the engine gets an immediate lock on the database, and no other threads may begin a transaction. Other threads may read from the database, but not write. With a ReadCommitted isolation level, locks are deferred and elevated as needed. It is possible for multiple threads to start a transaction in ReadCommitted mode, but if a thread attempts to commit a transaction while another thread has a ReadCommitted lock, it may timeout or cause a deadlock on both threads until both threads' CommandTimeout's are reached.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection.BeginTransaction
member.summary: Creates a new SQLiteTransaction if one isn't already active on the connection.

member.summary: The connection string containing the parameters for the connection

item.description:
Ticks - Use DateTime.Ticks
ISO8601 - Use ISO8601 DateTime format
JulianDay - Use JulianDay format

Yes/On/1 - Store GUID columns in binary form
No/Off/0 - Store GUID columns as text

Normal - Normal file flushing behavior
Full - Full flushing after all writes
Off - Underlying OS flushes I/O's

Y - Automatically enlist in distributed transactions
N - No automatic enlistment

True - Use connection pooling
False - Do not use connection pooling

True - Don't create the database if it does not exist, throw an error instead
False - Automatically create the database if it does not exist
{size in pages} - Limits the maximum number of pages (limits the size) of the database

True - Use the more compatible legacy 3.x database format
False - Use the newer 3.3x database format which compresses numbers more effectively

{time in seconds}
The default command timeout

Delete - Delete the journal file after a commit
Persist - Zero out and leave the journal file on disk after a commit
Off - Disable the rollback journal entirely

True - Open the database for read only access
False - Open the database for normal read/write access
The maximum number of connections for the given connection string that can be in the connection pool

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDateFormats
member.summary: This implementation of SQLite for ADO.NET can process date/time fields in databases in only one of three formats. Ticks, ISO8601 and JulianDay.
member.remarks:
ISO8601 is more compatible, readable, fully-processable, but less accurate as it doesn't provide time down to fractions of a second. JulianDay is the numeric format the SQLite uses internally and is arguably the most compatible with 3rd party tools. It is not readable as text without post-processing. Ticks less compatible with 3rd party tools that query the database, and renders the DateTime field unreadable as text without post-processing.
The preferred order of choosing a datetime format is JulianDay, ISO8601, and then Ticks. Ticks is mainly present for legacy code support.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDateFormats.Ticks
member.summary: Using ticks is not recommended and is not well supported with LINQ.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDateFormats.ISO8601
member.summary: The default format for this provider.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDateFormats.JulianDay
member.summary: JulianDay format, which is what SQLite uses internally

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteJournalModeEnum
member.summary: This enum determines how SQLite treats its journal file.
member.remarks:
By default SQLite will create and delete the journal file when needed during a transaction. However, for some computers running certain filesystem monitoring tools, the rapid creation and deletion of the journal file can cause those programs to fail, or to interfere with SQLite.
If a program or virus scanner is interfering with SQLite's journal file, you may receive errors like "unable to open database file" when starting a transaction. If this is happening, you may want to change the default journal mode to Persist.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteJournalModeEnum.Delete
member.summary: The default mode, this causes SQLite to create and destroy the journal file as-needed.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteJournalModeEnum.Persist
member.summary: When this is set, SQLite will keep the journal file even after a transaction has completed. It's contents will be erased, and the journal re-used as often as needed. If it is deleted, it will be recreated the next time it is needed.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteJournalModeEnum.Off
member.summary: This option disables the rollback journal entirely. Interrupted transactions or a program crash can cause database corruption in this mode!

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteDataReader.VerifyType(System.Int32,System.Data.DbType)
member.summary:
SQLite is inherently un-typed. All datatypes in SQLite are natively strings. The definition of the columns of a table and the affinity of returned types are all we have to go on to type-restrict data in the reader.
This function attempts to verify that the type of data being requested of a column matches the datatype of the column. In the case of columns that are not backed into a table definition, we attempt to match up the affinity of a column (int, double, string or blob) to a set of known types that closely match that affinity. It's not an exact science, but its the best we can do.
member.returns: This function throws an InvalidTypeCast() exception if the requested type doesn't match the column's definition or affinity.
member.param: The index of the column to type-check
The type we want to get out of the column

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction
member.summary: This abstract class is designed to handle user-defined functions easily. An instance of the derived class is made for each connection to the database.
member.remarks:
Although there is one instance of a class derived from SQLiteFunction per database connection, the derived class has no access to the underlying connection. This is necessary to deter implementers from thinking it would be a good idea to make database calls during processing.
It is important to distinguish between a per-connection instance, and a per-SQL statement context. One instance of this class services all SQL statements being stepped through on that connection, and there can be many. One should never store per-statement information in member variables of user-defined function classes.
For aggregate functions, always create and store your per-statement data in the contextData object on the 1st step. This data will be automatically freed for you (and Dispose() called if the item supports IDisposable) when the statement completes.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction._base
member.summary: The base connection this function is attached to

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction._contextDataList
member.summary: Internal array used to keep track of aggregate function context data

member.summary: Holds a reference to the callback function for user functions

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction._StepFunc
member.summary: Holds a reference to the callbakc function for stepping in an aggregate function

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction._FinalFunc
member.summary: Holds a reference to the callback function for finalizing an aggregate function

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction._CompareFunc
member.summary: Holds a reference to the callback function for collation sequences

member.summary: Current context of the current callback. Only valid during a callback

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction._registeredFunctions
member.summary: This static list contains all the user-defined functions declared using the proper attributes.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.#ctor
member.summary: Internal constructor, initializes the function's internal variables.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.Invoke(System.Object[])
member.summary: Scalar functions override this method to do their magic.
member.remarks: Parameters passed to functions have only an affinity for a certain data type, there is no underlying schema available to force them into a certain type. Therefore the only types you will ever see as parameters are DBNull.Value, Int64, Double, String or byte[] array.
member.param: The arguments for the command to process
member.returns: You may return most simple types as a return value, null or DBNull.Value to return null, DateTime, or you may return an Exception-derived class if you wish to return an error to SQLite. Do not actually throw the error, just return it!

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.Step(System.Object[],System.Int32,System.Object@)
member.summary: Aggregate functions override this method to do their magic.
member.remarks: Typically you'll be updating whatever you've placed in the contextData field and returning as quickly as possible.
member.param: The arguments for the command to process
The 1-based step number. This is incrememted each time the step method is called.
A placeholder for implementers to store contextual data pertaining to the current context.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.Final(System.Object)
member.summary: Aggregate functions override this method to finish their aggregate processing.
member.remarks: If you implemented your aggregate function properly, you've been recording and keeping track of your data in the contextData object provided, and now at this stage you should have all the information you need in there to figure out what to return. NOTE: It is possible to arrive here without receiving a previous call to Step(), in which case the contextData will be null. This can happen when no rows were returned. You can either return null, or 0 or some other custom return value if that is the case.
member.param: Your own assigned contextData, provided for you so you can return your final results.
member.returns: You may return most simple types as a return value, null or DBNull.Value to return null, DateTime, or you may return an Exception-derived class if you wish to return an error to SQLite. Do not actually throw the error, just return it!

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.Compare(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: User-defined collation sequences override this method to provide a custom string sorting algorithm.
member.param: The first string to compare
The second strnig to compare
member.returns: 1 if param1 is greater than param2, 0 if they are equal, or -1 if param1 is less than param2

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.ConvertParams(System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Converts an IntPtr array of context arguments to an object array containing the resolved parameters the pointers point to.
member.remarks: Parameters passed to functions have only an affinity for a certain data type, there is no underlying schema available to force them into a certain type. Therefore the only types you will ever see as parameters are DBNull.Value, Int64, Double, String or byte[] array.
member.param: The number of arguments
A pointer to the array of arguments
member.returns: An object array of the arguments once they've been converted to .NET values

member.summary: Takes the return value from Invoke() and Final() and figures out how to return it to SQLite's context.
member.param: The context the return value applies to
The parameter to return to SQLite

member.summary: Internal collation sequence function, which wraps up the raw string pointers and executes the Compare() virtual function.
member.param: Not used
Length of the string pv1
Pointer to the first string to compare
Length of the string pv2
Pointer to the second string to compare
member.returns: Returns -1 if the first string is less than the second. 0 if they are equal, or 1 if the first string is greater than the second.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.StepCallback(System.IntPtr,System.Int32,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: The internal aggregate Step function callback, which wraps the raw context pointer and calls the virtual Step() method.
member.remarks: This function takes care of doing the lookups and getting the important information put together to call the Step() function. That includes pulling out the user's contextData and updating it after the call is made. We use a sorted list for this so binary searches can be done to find the data.
member.param: A raw context pointer
Number of arguments passed in
A pointer to the array of arguments

member.param: A raw context pointer

member.summary: Placeholder for a user-defined disposal routine

member.summary: Disposes of any active contextData variables that were not automatically cleaned up. Sometimes this can happen if someone closes the connection while a DataReader is open.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.#cctor
member.summary: Using reflection, enumerate all assemblies in the current appdomain looking for classes that have a SQLiteFunctionAttribute attribute, and registering them accordingly.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.RegisterFunction(System.Type)
member.summary: Manual method of registering a function. The type must still have the SQLiteFunctionAttributes in order to work properly, but this is a workaround for the Compact Framework where enumerating assemblies is not currently supported.
member.param: The type of the function to register

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.BindFunctions(InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteBase)
member.summary: Called by SQLiteBase derived classes, this function binds all user-defined functions to a connection. It is done this way so that all user-defined functions will access the database using the same encoding scheme as the connection (UTF-8 or UTF-16).
member.remarks: The wrapper functions that interop with SQLite will create a unique cookie value, which internally is a pointer to all the wrapped callback functions. The interop function uses it to map CDecl callbacks to StdCall callbacks.
member.param: The base object on which the functions are to bind
member.returns: Returns an array of functions which the connection object should retain until the connection is closed.

member.name: P:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunction.SQLiteConvert
member.summary: Returns a reference to the underlying connection's SQLiteConvert class, which can be used to convert strings and DateTime's into the current connection's encoding schema.

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunctionEx
member.summary: Extends SQLiteFunction and allows an inherited class to obtain the collating sequence associated with a function call.
member.remarks: User-defined functions can call the GetCollationSequence() method in this class and use it to compare strings and char arrays.

member.name: M:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFunctionEx.GetCollationSequence
member.summary: Obtains the collating sequence in effect for the given function.

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.FunctionType
member.summary: The type of user-defined function to declare

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.FunctionType.Scalar
member.summary: Scalar functions are designed to be called and return a result immediately. Examples include ABS(), Upper(), Lower(), etc.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.FunctionType.Aggregate
member.summary: Aggregate functions are designed to accumulate data until the end of a call and then return a result gleaned from the accumulated data. Examples include SUM(), COUNT(), AVG(), etc.

member.name: F:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.FunctionType.Collation
member.summary: Collation sequences are used to sort textual data in a custom manner, and appear in an ORDER BY clause. Typically text in an ORDER BY is sorted using a straight case-insensitive comparison function. Custom collating sequences can be used to alter the behavior of text sorting in a user-defined manner.

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteFinalCallback
member.summary: An internal final callback delegate declaration.
member.param: Raw context pointer for the user function

member.name: T:InRule.Common.Data.SQLite.SQLiteCollation
member.summary: Internal callback delegate for implementing collation sequences
member.param: Not used
Length of the string pv1
Pointer to the first string to compare
Length of the string pv2
Pointer to the second string to compare
member.returns: Returns -1 if the first string is less than the second. 0 if they are equal, or 1 if the first string is greater than the second.

member.name: T:InRule.Runtime.Engine.State.Serialization.Xml.StateContainerXmlSerializer
member.summary: Provides a custom XML serialization and deserialization implementation for StateContainers, driven by their associated XsdTypeInfo metadata generated at Info build-time. Attempts to adhere closely to the w3.org XML Schema Definition language. The .NET framework's XmlSerializer class is not used here, and should not be used anywhere in the Runtime.

member.name: T:InRule.Runtime.CompileSettings
member.summary: Represents settings used to configure executable function compilation prior to use by a .

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.CompileSettings.Default
member.summary: An instance of the default settings using the default setting. Normally uses , but will use if Info logging is enabled.

member.name: M:InRule.Runtime.CompileSettings.Create(InRule.Runtime.EngineLogOptions)
member.summary: Creates a instance configured for a specific setting. Note: Multiple may be combined, e.g. | .
member.param: The specific to the function compilation.

member.name: M:InRule.Runtime.CompileSettings.Create(InRule.Runtime.EngineLogOptions,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a instance configured for specific and available processor cores. Note: Multiple may be combined, e.g. | .
member.param: The specific to the function compilation.

The maximum number of CPU cores/threads available for compiling executable functions (0 = use all available cores). Note that values other than overrides this setting and restricts usage to 1 core. 0 = use all available cores, 1 = single core (default), otherwise specifies max number of cores which can be used.

member.summary: The maximum number of CPU cores/threads available for compiling executable functions. 0 = use all available cores, 1 = single core (default), otherwise specifies max number of cores which can be used.

member.name: T:InRule.Runtime.DefaultRuleApplicationCachePolicy
member.summary: A cache policy providing finite depth, sliding expiration caching whose expiration policy is based on a weighting and last-used time. The last-used time is based on the last time a was created with a specific Rule Application, maintained on . Once the cache depth limit is reached, the Rule Applications with the lowest value and oldest last-used time will be flagged for expiration. Rule Applications cached with are not constrained by the cache depth limit and will never be flagged for expiration. Rule Applications cached with will never enter the cache. If the cache depth limit is less than 1, only Rule Applications with may enter the cache.

member.name: T:InRule.Runtime.IRuleApplicationCachePolicy
member.summary: Defines a cache policy interface which governs which Rule Applications may be cached and when to expire them.

member.name: M:InRule.Runtime.IRuleApplicationCachePolicy.AllowCacheEntry(InRule.Runtime.RuleApplicationReference,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{InRule.Runtime.RuleApplicationReference},System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{InRule.Runtime.RuleApplicationReference}@)
member.summary: Determines whether the should cache this item, and whether there are any existing Rule Applications that should be expired from the cache.
member.param: The Rule Application to cache.
A collection of existing Rule Applications currently in the cache.
A collection of existing Rule Application to be expired from the cache. This may be null if there is none.
member.returns: true if the candidate should enter the cache; otherwise false.

member.summary: The default cache depth. This may be overriden in the .config file, or by explicitly configuring a new cache policy via the SDK.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of using a specified cache depth limit.

member.summary: Ensures a Rule Application will never be removed from the cache by the cache policy. It may be explicitly removed using the Remove() or Clear() methods on the RuleSession.RuleApplicationCache. Its weight is equivalent to .

member.summary: The default cache retention weight used if no CacheRetention argument is used. Default weight = 1000.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.CacheRetention.Weight
member.summary: The cache retention weight. Higher values are more likely to be retained; Lower valies are less likely to be retained and therefore expired from the cache. 1000 is the default weight.

member.name: T:InRule.Runtime.CatalogRefreshSettings
member.summary: Governs the execution refresh behavior for rule applications stored in the InRule catalog service. When a is created, it may check for an updated revision of a rule application if the latest revision or label was specified for the . The refresh interval governs the minimum time between catalog revision checks and therefore how long to use a potentially stale cached rule application. The failure limit governs how long to use a cached rule application if the catalog service is unavailable during a revision check.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.CatalogRefreshSettings.Default
member.summary: The default setting. The default refresh interval is 30 seconds, and failure limit is 2 hours, unless changed in the .config file.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.CatalogRefreshSettings.NeverCheckLatestRevision
member.summary: Disables catalog revision check refresh and uses a cached revision if available.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.CatalogRefreshSettings.AlwaysCheckLatestRevision
member.summary: Forces catalog revision check refresh every time a is created, if configured to use the latest revision or specific label.

member.name: M:InRule.Runtime.CatalogRefreshSettings.#ctor(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of .
member.param: The minimum rule application refresh interval that specifies when to check the catalog for an updated revision, if latest revision or label was specified. The refresh only occurs when a new is created. Use TimeSpan.Zero to refresh every time, or TimeSpan.MaxValue to disable refresh. Default = 30 seconds.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.CatalogRefreshSettings.RefreshInterval
member.summary: Gets the minimum rule application refresh interval that specifies when to check the catalog for an updated revision, if latest revision or label was specified. The refresh only occurs when a new is created. TimeSpan.Zero means refresh every time, TimeSpan.MaxValue means disable refresh. Default = 30 seconds.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.BoundStateSettings.BindOnlyToConfiguredStateDelegates
member.summary: If true, tells the engine to use *only* configured delegates for state operations (field reads/writes, collection operations, etc.). An error is thrown if no delegate exists for a given operation for a given schema element. If false, the engine will attempt to use configured delegates if they exist, otherwise it will fall back to state access behavior specified by BindingMode.

member.summary: Disables messages, value changes, statistics and generation.

member.summary: Enables text feedback messages and rule changes on the . This includes RuleSet, Rule and Action execution messages.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.EngineLogOptions.StateChanges
member.summary: Enables state changes on the , including calculations.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.EngineLogOptions.SummaryStatistics
member.summary: Enables summary statistics in and .

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.EngineLogOptions.DetailStatistics
member.summary: Enables detailed statistics in . This enables RuleSet, Rule and Action timings.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.EngineLogOptions.RuleTrace
member.summary: Enables generation. This is accessible from .

member.name: T:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.ThreadLocal`1
member.summary: Provides fast strongly typed thread local storage. This is significantly faster than Thread.GetData/SetData.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Utils.ThreadLocal`1.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary:
True if the caller will guarantee that all cleanup happens as the thread unwinds.
This is typically used in a case where the thread local is surrounded by a try/finally block. The try block pushes some state, the finally block restores the previous state. Therefore when the thread exits the thread local is back to it's original state. This allows the ThreadLocal object to not check the current owning thread on retrieval.

member.name: M:System.Dynamic.Utils.TypeUtils.CanCache(System.Type)
member.summary: We can cache references to types, as long as they aren't in collectable assemblies. Unfortunately, we can't really distinguish between different flavors of assemblies. But, we can at least create a whitelist for types in mscorlib (so we get the primitives) and System.Core (so we find Func/Action overloads, etc).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.CallInstruction.SlowCreate(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,System.Reflection.ParameterInfo[])
member.summary: Uses reflection to create new instance of the appropriate ReflectedCaller

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.CallInstruction.FastCreate(System.Reflection.MethodInfo,System.Reflection.ParameterInfo[])
member.summary:
Fast creation works if we have a known primitive types for the entire method siganture. If we have any non-primitive types then FastCreate falls back to SlowCreate which works for all types.
Fast creation is fast because it avoids using reflection (MakeGenericType and Activator.CreateInstance) to create the types. It does this through calling a series of generic methods picking up each strong type of the signature along the way. When it runs out of types it news up the appropriate CallInstruction with the strong-types that have been built up.
One relaxation is that for return types which are non-primitive types we can fallback to object due to relaxed delegates.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.CallInstruction.ArgumentCount
member.summary: The number of arguments including "this" for instance methods.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.GotoInstruction
member.summary:
This instruction implements a goto expression that can jump out of any expression. It pops values (arguments) from the evaluation stack that the expression tree nodes in between the goto expression and the target label node pushed and not consumed yet. A goto expression can jump into a node that evaluates arguments only if it carries a value and jumps right after the first argument (the carried value will be used as the first argument). Goto can jump into an arbitrary child of a BlockExpression since the block doesnt accumulate values on evaluation stack as its child expressions are being evaluated.
Goto needs to execute any finally blocks on the way to the target label.
{ f(1, 2, try { g(3, 4, try { goto L } finally { ... }, 6) } finally { ... }, 7, 8) L: ... }
The goto expression here jumps to label L while having 4 items on evaluation stack (1, 2, 3 and 4). The jump needs to execute both finally blocks, the first one on stack level 4 the second one on stack level 2. So, it needs to jump the first finally block, pop 2 items from the stack, run second finally block and pop another 2 items from the stack and set instruction pointer to label L.
Goto also needs to rethrow ThreadAbortException iff it jumps out of a catch handler and the current thread is in "abort requested" state.

member.summary: The first instruction of finally block.

member.summary: The last instruction of finally block.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.InterpretedFrame.GroupStackFrames(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Diagnostics.StackFrame})
member.summary: A single interpreted frame might be represented by multiple subsequent Interpreter.Run CLR frames. This method filters out the duplicate CLR frames.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.Interpreter
member.summary:
A simple forth-style stack machine for executing Expression trees without the need to compile to IL and then invoke the JIT. This trades off much faster compilation time for a slower execution performance. For code that is only run a small number of times this can be a sweet spot.
The core loop in the interpreter is the RunInstructions method.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.Interpreter.Run(Microsoft.Scripting.Interpreter.InterpretedFrame)
member.summary: Runs instructions within the given frame.
member.remarks: Interpreted stack frames are linked via Parent reference so that each CLR frame of this method corresponds to an interpreted stack frame in the chain. It is therefore possible to combine CLR stack traces with interpreted stack traces by aligning interpreted frames to the frames of this method. Each group of subsequent frames of Run method corresponds to a single interpreted frame.

summary.nullHandling: Yes: Numeric expression is cast to an Int32. null -> 0
summary.performance: Medium: Performs initial range check using expressions, and calls System.Convert.ToChar() delegate if valid.

summary.nullHandling: Yes: Function uses String.Join(), which handles null values in the string array
Yes: Value expressions are first cast to either Decimal or DateTime, so null -> 0. If format expression is null, the Value expression is returned unchanged.
summary.performance: Medium: Calls either System.Decimal.ToString() or System.DateTime.ToString() delegates.

summary.cultureAware: No: We are assuming that checking for the existance of whitespace (leading, trailing and duplicates) is not dependent on culture.
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Value expression has an explicit null check.
summary.performance: Medium: Calls into static method to perform single iteration of char array, giving O(n) performance.

summary.nullHandling: Yes: Null checking on both args: null -> String.Empty.

summary.cultureAware: Partial: Does not honor string culture settings (Neither does InRule3.x). Uses ordinal compare of each character using Char.Equals(). This behavior needs to be evaluated and is tracked in backlog task #20304. Partial because the case-insensitive check uses culture-specific Char.ToUpper().
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null checks on both value and pattern.
summary.performance: Medium: Calls into either case-sensitive or case-insensitive static methods to perform single iteration of both char arrays giving O(n) performance on size of pattern string. Case-insensitive version performs culture-specific Char.ToUpper() on each character comparison, although this is ~15 times slower than the case-sensitive version.

summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on value expression. NumChars arg is cast to Decimal, so null -> 0.
summary.performance: Medium: Calls String.SubString() delegate. Includes bounds checking on both arg inputs like InRule3.x function.

summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on value expression.
Yes: Explicit null check on input value: null -> String.Empty, and start+length params are cast to Int32: null -> 0.
summary.performance: Medium: Performs null and range checks and calls String.SubString() delegate.

summary.cultureAware: Yes: TextInfo.ToTitleCase() function used is sourced from the current CultureInfo object.
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on input value: null -> String.Empty.
summary.performance: Medium: Performs null check and calls CultureInfo.TextInfo.ToTitleCase(value.ToLower()) delegate.

summary.cultureAware: No: Uses String.Replace() function which uses an ordinal, case-sensitive string comparer.
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on input values: null -> String.Empty.
summary.performance: Medium: Performs null checks and calls String.Replace() delegate.

summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on value expression. NumChars arg is cast to Decimal, so null -> 0.
summary.performance: Medium: Calls String.SubString() delegate. Includes bounds checking on both arg inputs like InRule3.x function.

summary.cultureAware: Yes: Uses String.ToLower() which is culture-specific.
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on input value: null -> String.Empty.
summary.performance: Medium: Performs null check and calls String.ToLower() delegate.

summary.cultureAware: Yes: Uses String.ToUpper() which is culture-specific.
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on input value: null -> String.Empty.
summary.performance: Medium: Performs null check and calls String.ToUpper() delegate.

summary.cultureAware: No: Other than following whitespace rules from Char.IsWhitespace() that applies to all cultures.
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on input value: null -> String.Empty.
summary.performance: Medium: Performs null check and calls String.Trim() delegate.

summary.cultureAware: No: Other than following whitespace rules from Char.IsWhitespace() that applies to all cultures.
summary.nullHandling: Yes: Explicit null check on input value: null -> String.Empty.
summary.performance: Medium: Calls into static method to perform single iteration of char array, giving O(n) performance.

member.summary: Returns an identical copy of this instance.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.RuleSessionSettings.UseAuthoredTypeInformationForTempFields
member.summary: Specifies whether to use authoring-time CLR type information for temp fields during creation of their associated values. Set this to false when using XElement binding to ensure temp fields ignore any authoring-time CLR type info. Defaults to true.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.RuleSessionSettings.MaxExecutionCores
member.summary: The maximum number of CPU cores/threads available to the rule engine for rule execution. Note that setting to anything other than overrides this setting and restricts usage to 1 core. 0 = use all available cores, 1 = single core (default), otherwise specifies max number of cores which can be used.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.RuleSessionSettings.LogOptions
member.summary: Provides granular configuration of engine logging options.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.RuleSessionSettings.Now
member.summary: Allows override of current date and time used by the Now() and Today() functions. If not set, each rule execution will use DateTime.Now.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.RuleSessionSettings.ExecutionTimeout
member.summary: The default execution timeout is 30 seconds; use TimeSpan.Zero for infinite timeout.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.RuleSessionSettings.MaxCycleCount
member.summary: The maximum number of core engine operations (value reads, value writes, rule executions) allowed for a given execution request.

member.name: P:InRule.Runtime.RuleSessionSettings.EnableXsdValidationOnInternalSchema
member.summary: Specifies whether XSD schema validation will be performed on load for internal-schema entities.

remarks.para: If this is explicitly set at runtime, it overrides the setting on
The default setting is true, in which case any fields in loaded XML for an internal-schema entity that are not present as Entity StateLocation fields will result in an xsd validation exception.
When this setting is false, any extraneous fields will simply be ignored on load, with no error.

member.name: T:InRule.Runtime.RuleExecutionLog
member.summary:
Contains runtime diagnostic statistics and messages optionally collected during rule execution. Log options are bitwise-OR'ed together to specify the desired collection level; collecting more log information will result in slower performance, while collecting less will result in better performance. To configure log options:
myRuleSession.Settings.LogOptions = EngineLogOptions.Changes | EngineLogOptions.Statistics; // omits execution-specific messages...

member.name: T:InRule.Runtime.Engine.State.EntityOrigin
member.summary: EntityOrigin defines lifetime management policy for entity container instances.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.Engine.State.EntityOrigin.RootSDK
member.summary: Rooted entity container lifetime is tied to their parent session state. They can be cleaned up manually by the end user, or automatically upon session teardown.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.Engine.State.EntityOrigin.NonRootSDK
member.summary: Non-rooted entity container lifetime is tied to their parent container(s). When a non-rooted entity is no longer referenced from any other state location, it is removed from memory. The presence of an SDK reference to this entity will not prevent it from being removed.

member.name: F:InRule.Runtime.Engine.State.EntityOrigin.Internal
member.summary: Similar semantics as NonRoot, but used to distinguish between explicitly created (non-root) entities and those created internally during rule execution.
